annotation.TEXT: Thankfully, these lasers aren't instant kills (they just deal a ton of damage). For those of you that are disappointed by this for whatever reason, don't worry: There's a certain brand of laser in one of the next areas that will probably satiate your twisted desires.

Getting stunned in this game is more annoying than it sounds. When you're stunned, the only things that can free you are getting hit by another enemy's attack, or just sitting around and waiting for the effect to wear off (note: as the enemies upgrade through-out the later stages, the stun-time increases). The same thing actually applies to any stun-inducing chips you use, which is partly why it's not worth using them.

The 1st variations of stun chips don't last long. Anything other than 3rd variations of stun effects is (ironically enough) a waste of time. Even then, the stun effect is botched by one simple factor: If you hit a stunned enemy with anything (even a single, uncharged buster pellet), the stun effect immediately wears off. This is the reason why I don't use any variations of Zap Ring in this game (not to mention that its damage scaling is actually worse than it is the original BN series).

Let's not mince words here: BrightMan.EXE is one of the most annoying bosses in the entire game. He's essentially supposed to serve as one of two potential introductions to a boss gimmick that we'll be seeing way too much of: Counter attacks. Any time you hit him, he'll negate the damage of your attack completely and counter with a tracing energy beam. The trick to this fight is to hit him, then immediately follow up with a chip attack while his counter defenses are down.

Oh, and on that note: Don't try to pass through his counter defense with Navi chips (because even though they stop time briefly, they still won't do any damage if his counter hasn't been triggered yet).

In terms of re-fighting NeedleMan.EXE, the same strategy used on FireMan.EXE applies here: Abuse elemental weaknesses. If you have enough money, buy some Heat-V chips from Higsby's. Five shots from this chip is enough to put him down and ensure an S Rank.

Shockwave might not be the best solution to this fight, but in the very least, it can get you through your first encounter with this guy (the timing for sliding underneath his beam attacks is very strict, though).

NeedleMan.EXE's Navi chip basically sprays out needles in a downwards spread-pattern in front of you. As for his ability chip, the Needle Cannon is actually pretty decent. While its base damage seems low, it fires and hits multiple times. Once again: Good for minor enemies, terrible for bosses or anything else that has invincibility frames.
As a side-note: I'm not sure what happened with the lighting effects in this place. It only lasts for the first part of this room, though.

We now return to your semi-regularly scheduled internet shenanigans. Aside from real life stuff, a part of the reason this segment took longer to come out is mainly due to off-screen grinding. I needed to get enough zenny to buy a few copies of a specific battle chip for the NeedleMan.EXE re-fight, along with some new armor and an Unlocker for the next area.

The Shopping District is one of the smallest areas in the whole game. With that being said, it's no less dangerous, if only for the annoying stun-inducing attacks from the enemies here. I'll state this right now: I hate the stun effects in this game, both in the way the enemies use it and how you're given the opportunity to use it.
^ Terrible reward, even for this point in the game.
